7.53pm GMT

6.16pm GMT

Britainâ€™s high street might be in better shape if it could sell tickets to watch Mike Ashley in action.

In an eye-catching performance, the man behind Sports Direct has unveiled a new plan to tackle Britainâ€™s high street -- a tax on web retailers, to encourage them to keep high bricks-and-mortar outlets running too.

Ashley, though, insisted that the high street was otherwise doomed, saying:

The high street wonâ€™t make 2030, it wonâ€™t get there, unless you do something really radical and grab the bulls by the horns.

MPs on the Housing, Communities and Local Government Committee, who are looking at the future of the high street in 2030, looked sceptical -- asking how overseas-based e-tailers could be made to pay the levy.

Ashley arrived at the Thatcher Room in Westminster, keen to give MPs the benefits of his experience running Sports Direct. But he swiftly found himself on the back foot, as MPs demanded answers about his takeover of House of Fraser this year.

Ashley also found that MPs havenâ€™t forgotten Sports Directâ€™s reputation for using zero-hours contracts (it was criticised for Victorian workhouse practices in 2016).

He refused to rule out using more zero-hours contracts at HoF, insisting that many workers love them. And he denied â€œstroking a white catâ€� like a Bond villain, deciding which stores to axe.

Updated at 6.30pm GMT

5.37pm GMT

And finally, Mike Ashley hinted that House of Fraser could work closer with Debenhams (in which he owns a stake).

He tol MPs:

â€œI told them to work together. They should work together

5.25pm GMT

Mike Ashley winds up his hearing with a prediction -- Harrods and Selfridges will have a good year.

One of the reasons that House of Fraser failed is that it didnâ€™t elevate itself, Ashley continues.

Luxury brands are on the up. Teenagers, people today, want to wear their wealth.

5.22pm GMT

Ashley: Retail will be a ghost town outside London

Mike Ashley returns to his big theme - the internet has killed the high street.

He tells the MPs:

The web has killed the high street, not the local councils, not this, not that.

Ashley concedes that everyone involved may have moved too slowly to tackle the issue. Now, unless major change is pushed through, the high street is finished.

It is just going to die, and youâ€™ll be left with Oxford Street and Bond Street.

Outside of London, itâ€™s going to be a ghost town. Sorry, thatâ€™s what itâ€™s going to be.

5.15pm GMT

Interestingly, Mike Ashley says that local councils have helped keep House of Fraser stores open since his Sports Direct chain took it over this year.

Ashley tells the committee that some landlords have refused to cut the rent, in the hope that the department store will close - freeing them up potentially turn it into housing.

Councils, though, insisted that everyone involved made an effort to keep the House of Fraser store open.

Ashley suggests, though, that some stores need to downside - perhaps by turning their upper floors into residential units.

I accept House of Fraser cannot have 500,000 square feet in Birmingham. Honestly, you would need an Uber to take you round. Itâ€™s ridiculous.

5.01pm GMT

Q: There are reports that high street rents might crash next year, by 20%. Wouldnâ€™t that be good news for the retailers? But wouldnâ€™t rents NOT fall, if landlords were able to turn high street stores into residential units (as some campaigners have asked for)

Youâ€™ll make me hated by every landlord in the country, but youâ€™re absolutely correct, Ashley replies.

4.59pm GMT

Labour MP Liz Twist, who represents the Bladon in North-East England, asks Mr Ashley to meet with her to discuss the fate of the House of Fraser Metro store.

No, absolutely not, Ashey replies.

Q: Why not?

If I do it for one person, think of all the other people that I have let down, Ashley replies, burying his head in his hands.

People keep thinking I can do these one-off things. Itâ€™s not easy to do,

But Ashley is prepared to attend a meeting with MPs to discuss the wider issue, ideally with HoFs landlords too.

4.53pm GMT

Q: Whatâ€™s happening with House of Fraser stores, and your push to cut rents?

Mike Ashley says local councils are refusing to cut rents, because they can see that HoF stores are profitable...but theyâ€™re not recognising the overhead costs behind the scenes.

So a store that seems to be making a Â£2m profit on paper is actually losing Â£2m, once you factor in the true costs of running a business.

Ashley then give a fascinating insight into business, saying that accountants can make up nearly any number you like, to flatter a companyâ€™s accounts.

You donâ€™t even understand what theyâ€™re talking about, and theyâ€™ll say â€˜I can make that store loss-making, or I can make it profitableâ€™.

They say â€œIâ€™ll put exceptions in - what are they when theyâ€™re at home?â€� Ashley adds with (apparent) disbelief.

4.46pm GMT

The underlying problem in UK retail is the web, says Mike Ashley, as he continues to brief MPs on the future of the high street.

Looking magnanimously at the Housing, Communities and Local Government Committee, he adds kindly:

Itâ€™s not your fault, you didnâ€™t do it.

4.45pm GMT

Q: Why is there such a problem with rents in the retail sector?

Landlords and retailers have always been uneasy bedfellows, says Mike Ashley. And whenever one has the upper hand, he â€œgets out his hammerâ€� and bashes the other one.

He says â€œgood luckâ€� to any landlord who owns highly lucrative land on Bond Street.

But heâ€™s more critical of landlords who have got retailers on contracts where rents can only rise. Those rental agreements are a â€œdownward death spiral....â€�

Ashley blames successful companies, such as McDonalds and his own Sports Direct chain, which agreed to hefty rent deals in the good times - which everyone else was then moved onto as well.

4.41pm GMT

If youâ€™re just tuning into Mike Ashleyâ€™s hearing on the future of the high street, hereâ€™s what youâ€™ve missed...

4.38pm GMT

Mike Ashley now concedes that it would be difficult to implement his plan for a new tax on web companies, but insists that itâ€™s simple in principle.

[Reminder, the idea is a new levy on any retailer who does over 20% of its business online]

Q: Many retailers say that the solution is lower business rates and free parking..

Yes, but whoâ€™s going to pay for it, Ashley shoots back.

He admits that Sports Direct, which he founded, would be hit in the pocket if the government took up his suggestion of a new tax on e-tailers.

Sports Direct wonâ€™t be pleased with me for my suggestion. Itâ€™s not necessarily a good fix for Sports Direct , but itâ€™s a fantastic fix for the high street.

Otherwise, Ashley argues, the high street is destined for destruction:

The high street wonâ€™t make 2030, it wonâ€™t get there, unless you do something really radical and grab the bulls by the horns.

4.31pm GMT

Q: How would your plan for a new tax on web retailers work when people buy goods from abroad?

In theory you could still tax them, Ashley insists, but agrees that overseas retailers would have to sign up to pay it.

You want to get retailers saving the high street, he adds - through a new tax on companies who make most of their money selling online only.

4.28pm GMT

High stores have to change, itâ€™s not just about a sea of clothing any more, says Mike Ashley.

He suggests retailers need to be much more innovative -- maybe with different opening hours, more self-service tills.

Updated at 4.29pm GMT

4.20pm GMT

In another burst of blue-sky thinking, Mike Ashley suggests high street stores could offer services such as free computer gaming to lure customers in.

4.18pm GMT

Retail analyst Neil Saunders isnâ€™t impressed:

4.17pm GMT

Hereâ€™s some video clips of Mike Ashley in action:

4.11pm GMT

Mike Ashley now insists that he doesnâ€™t â€œsit in an office stroking a white catâ€�, trying to decide which House of Fraser stores to shut following this yearâ€™s takeover.

Of course Iâ€™m worried about the state of the high street, he continues.

Itâ€™s not my fault the high streetâ€™s dying, is it? Itâ€™s not House of Fraserâ€™s fault, itâ€™s not Marks & Spencerâ€™s fault, itâ€™s not Debenhamâ€™s fault.

Itâ€™s very simple why the high street is dying - itâ€™s the internet. The internet is killing the high street.

Thatâ€™s quite a statement, given Sports Direct has hundreds of stores in the UK, just bought House of Fraser, and also has a stake in Debenhams.

But Ashley has a cunning plan -- a new tax on web-only retailers, to encourage them to maintain a high street presence too.

Updated at 5.29pm GMT

4.02pm GMT

Ashley: Only God could keep all House of Fraser's stores open

Q: You promised to turn House of Fraser into the Harrods of the high street and keep its 59 stores open, but now people are worried that their local store will close. How will you decide which stores to shut?

Ashley looks like heâ€™s going to burst a blood vessel.

I never said I would keep 59 stores over. Never, never, never...

What person could keep 59 stores open - beside God? Itâ€™s impossible, it canâ€™t be done.

Even keeping 80% open would be messianic, Ashley indicates, before adding modestly that heâ€™s not comparing himself to God.

Updated at 4.03pm GMT

3.56pm GMT

Mike Ashley: Workers love zero-hours contracts

Over in the UK parliament, the boss of retailer Sports Direct is testifying to MPs about the future of the high street.

But Mike Ashley actually finds himself fending off tough questions about his companyâ€™s business practices, following the takeover of House of Fraser.

First off, heâ€™s accused of letting customers down - by not refunding orders placed online just before House of Fraser went into administration. Ashley insists that customers received gift cards instead, as SPD got to grips with the companyâ€™s problems.

Ashley then asked whether heâ€™ll be putting House of Fraser staff onto zero-hours contracts, something heâ€™s been criticised for using heavily at Sports Direct.

Ashley insists that â€œthe vast majority of staff love themâ€�, but he wonâ€™t commit not to roll them out more heavily at HoF.

Getting impassioned, Ashley insists that he needs to keep all options open.

â€œI canâ€™t, itâ€™s impossible what youâ€™re asking. It doesnâ€™t make sense.

The high street has to change what it offers consumers.

That means stores might need to open later, and close later, Ashley suggests, telling MPs firmly:

Stop trying to showboat... I thought we were here to save the high street.

3.37pm GMT

For all Donald Trumpâ€™s optimism, many financial analysts are unconvinced that the US and China can settle their trade dispute in just 90 days.

Reforming Beijing treatment of intellectual property will take much longer, and thereâ€™s only so much US produce which China can really absorb to help mop up the trade gap.

But still, the markets are up.

And thatâ€™s because the immediate threat of a deeper trade war has receded.

As Aninda Mitra, senior sovereign analyst at BNY Mellon Investment Management, puts it:

â€œTo be sure, underlying problems remain unresolved. It is not as though existing tariffs are on the verge of being unwound. But what Xi has managed to extract from Trump is a stay on any escalation for three months. That interlude should see a stronger effort to set a framework for more talks and quid-pro quos.

In the long term, though, achieving full trade dÃ©tente will be tricky:

â€œThe best one can hope for in three monthsâ€™ time is a trade and geopolitical deal in which we see a road-map for China to materially raise oil and agriculture imports from the U.S. to cut the bilateral surplus by more than one-half in about 1-2 yearsâ€™ time. That will result in a diversion of Chinese imports from U.S. foes such as Russia and Iran, and possibly Saudi and rest of OPEC. I would imagine the Chinese would also acquiesce to at least some softening of U.S. access to technology and finance in China. Signals to this effect came from Xi suggesting he would not object to the Qualcomm-NXP deal if this were presented again.

â€œThe highest priority for the Chinese authorities at the moment is to stabilize their economy. In this context, a 90-day truce should boost local sentiment, and prove more important from a psychological standpoint than recent policy stimulus which was seen as tepid, if not grudging.

3.13pm GMT

In another boost to the White House, the US manufacturing sector has posted another month of strong growth.

The Institute for Supply Management has reported that new orders, employment levels and activity also jumped last month, while the prices paid by manufacturers fell.

This drove ISMâ€™s monthly healthcheck on Americaâ€™s factory sector up to 59.3. from 57.7. That level is consistent with strong growth.

3.02pm GMT

There are some major names among the big movers on Wall Street today.

Aircraft maker Boeing has gained 6%, construction and machinery business Caterpillar is up 4%, and Apple has gained 2.6%. That suggests investors are optimistic that the trade war time-out will yield results.

Chipmakers AMD (+7.8%) and NVIDIA (+6%) are also romping ahead.

Randeep Somel, Director of Global Equities at M&G, explains why markets are upbeat:

The rally seen this morning in equity markets show that the escalating trade disputes are a significant concern to the global growth outlook of the world economy. Whilst its very early days and the process of normalising the trading relationship with China is going to be a complex process â€“ today, at the very least is a signal that those negotiations can begin.

Riskier assets such as base metals and oil producers, as well as the US and European car manufacturers and associated supply chains are likely to show the most positive reflection of the news as they have borne the brunt of the negative headlines for most of this year.â€�

2.54pm GMT

2.36pm GMT

Wall Street jumps on trade war relief

After a minuteâ€™s silence to honour President George H.W Bush, Wall Street has opened, and shares are rallying hard.

The Dow Jones industrial average has jumped by 412 points, or 1.6%, to 25,950, in early trading, following upbeat comments from Donald Trump and Stephen Mnuchin in the last couple of hours.

The broader S&P 500 index is up 1.5%, while the Nasdaq has gained 2%.

Industrial stocks and technology firms are leading the rally, on relief that the US will not be imposing tougher tariffs on China -- at least not for 90 days.

Nick Payne, head of global emerging market equities, Merian Global Investors, says investors around the globe are feeling much cheerier.

â€œThe 90-day truce in the Sino-US trade war agreed between President Xi and President Trump in Buenos Aires is a welcome development in reducing tension.

The very fact that both sides have reopened dialogue is a good step forward and should help sentiment and asset prices in emerging markets. Of course, hard yards lie ahead in reaching a comprehensive agreement, but for now, both sides can claim a â€œwinâ€�. US consumers can cheer that their manufactured-in-China favourites like iPhones will not be increasing in price for Christmas.

2.28pm GMT

Donald Trump is claiming that Chinaâ€™s promise to cut tariffs on US car imports, from 40%, is a win.

However, Beijing only raised the tariff to 40% this summer after the US launched its trade war. A few months earlier, China actually cut the tariff from 25% to 15%.

Brad Setser of the Council of Foreign Relations reckons the tariff wonâ€™t be slashed below 15%.

2.18pm GMT

1.24pm GMT

Speaking on CNBC a few moments ago, Mnuchin says that the 90-day hiatus is a significant step:

This is the first time that we have a commitment from them that this will be a real agreement.

However...Mnuchin added that Beijing to follow through on its commitments, and open its economy more widely, and fairly, to US companies:

â€œThey put on the table an offer of over $1.2 trillion in additional commitments. But the details of that still need to be negotiated.

This isnâ€™t just about buying things. This is about opening markets to U.S. companies and protecting U.S. technology. Those are very important structural issues to the president.â€�

1.21pm GMT

More optimism from the White House:

1.03pm GMT

Trump: We've taken a BIG leap forward with China

The US president is awake, and in an effusive mood after his negotiations with Xi Jinping on Saturday night.

Donald Trump is tweeting that the trade truce can be a win for both the US and China -- a point analysts have also made today.

Salman Ahmed, chief investment strategist at Lombard Odier IM, agrees that Trump and Xi made a breakthrough:

â€œThe much anticipated dinner between the two leaders resulted in the first major breakthrough since talks broke down in May. For now, China has agreed to buy more US products, including agricultural goods, and to tackle the trade imbalance concern. President Xi also agreed to designate fentanyl a controlled substance, in a move which was described as a â€œwonderful humanitarian gestureâ€� in a statement issued by the White House on Saturday.

â€œOn trade, President Trump said the US will not go ahead with the implementation of a 25% tariff rate scheduled for January. The tariffs on $200 billion worth of products will be left at the 10% rate for the next 90 days while both parties attempt to negotiate structural changes.

â€œSigns of rapprochement between China and the US is certainly good news. This does not reflect a definitive shift in the relationship between the US and China, but the opening up of negotiations is certainly a big step in the right direction.

12.55pm GMT

Stephen Cooper, Head of Industrial Manufacturing at KPMG UK, is concerned by todayâ€™s UK factory data (even though anxious stockpiling drove growth up):

â€œBrexit and supply chain worries have dented Novemberâ€™s UK manufacturing data, with muted growth and optimism at a 27-month low.

â€œThe continued decline in export orders is something manufacturers need to be mindful of, particularly as the Eurozoneâ€™s Manufacturing PMI numbers for last month were relatively flat and there are are also wider global demand concerns. With the Eurozone as such an important market for the UK, manufacturers need to prepare carefully for Brexit and ensure they understand every aspect of their supply chains.â€�

12.51pm GMT

12.43pm GMT

Hereâ€™s a handy chart showing how the trade dispute intensified this year, as the US and China exchanged tit-for-tat tariffs.

11.58am GMT

Influential investor Mohamed A. El-Erian of Allianz reckons the US-China trade truce is a quadruple win, at least in the short term.

He writes:

At the end of almost three hours of what the White House called â€œhighly successfulâ€� discussions, the U.S. agreed to refrain for 90 days from implementing additional tariffs on $200 billion of imports from China. In return, China promised to use the time to make progress in three areas of concern to the U.S. and other countries: relaxing an array of nontariff barriers, including joint-venture requirements, that result in forced transfers of technology, operational models and other proprietary information and business practices; combatting intellectual property theft and other cyber interferences; and reducing the bilateral trade surplus by importing â€œvery substantialâ€� quantities of certain goods from the U.S.

This outcome is a short-term win for both sides, as well as the global economy:

The U.S. defines a time-specific way forward to counter practices that place it at a competitive disadvantage in its bilateral economic relationship with China. And the world economy is in a better place, for now, to avoid a stagflationary trade war.

It is also a short-term win for investors and markets:

El-Erian adds that the world economy would have suffered if the talks had broken down. However, both sides now have to work â€œcooperativelyâ€� to turn this truce into a long-term deal.

Thereâ€™s also a danger that the new 90-day deadline creates fresh political pressures, which will weigh on markets in early 2019.

11.41am GMT

11.40am GMT

If they cancel the extra 25 percent tariff on US-made cars, then we will see positive signs for imported cars,â€�

Shares in European car companies are surging, after Donald Trump tweeted that China has agreed to cut tariffs on auto imports.

Daimler are leading the pack, up 7%, in Germany followed by BMW (+6.6%) and Volkswagen (+4%). They all have factories in the US, so should benefit from a cooling in trade war tensions. Tire maker Continental is up 3.5%.

Ted Baker says it will investigate the case, adding:

Shares in the company have fallen to Â£15.86 (from Â£18.26), their lowest level since June 2013.

9.53am GMT

9.43am GMT

UK factory growth beats forecasts

Newsflash: Britainâ€™s manufacturing was unexpectedly strong last month, as companies rush to stockpile products ahead of a Brexit crisis.

Markitâ€™s UK factory PMI, which measures activity in the sector, has jumped to 53.1 for November, up from Octoberâ€™s 27-month low of 51.1.

Most of the demand came from domestic customers amid a rush to fill inventories with important products and components, in case of trade disruption after Brexit.

But the export picture is darker -- new orders from overseas shrank for the second straight month in November, the first back-to-back contraction since early-2016.

Rob Dobson, Director at IHS Markit, points out that manufacturers are still quite pessimistic.

â€œWhile demand from the domestic market was a positive spur, in some cases as clients built up stocks in response to Brexit and other supply-chain uncertainties, manufacturers also reported a further decrease in new export business as slower global economic growth and Brexit worries took a bite out of foreign demand.

Brexit worries also increasingly dominated the outlook for the sector. Although still forecasting growth for the year ahead, manufacturersâ€™ confidence fell to its lowest ebb since August 2016.â€�

Overnight, manufacturing group EEF also reported that UK manufacturers have been working hard, stockpiling products ahead a possible cliff-edge Brexit.

Related: UK manufacturers stockpile goods ahead of Brexit

9.28am GMT

Italy and France were the worst-performing regions:

  • Netherlands 56.1: 25-month low
  • Austria 54.9: 2-month high
  • Ireland 55.4: 2-month high
  • Greece 54.0: 6-month high
  • Spain 52.6: 3-month high
  • Germany 51.8 (flash: 51.6) 31-month low
  • France 50.8 (flash: 50.7) 26-month low
  • Italy 48.6: 47-month low

On the upside, itâ€™s better than the initial â€˜flashâ€™ estimate released mid-way through the month (51.5).

9.12am GMT

UBS analyst Paul Donovan suggests investors shouldnâ€™t get too excited about the US-China trade truce.

US President Trump may, metaphorically, be claiming to have a tweet on Twitter that promises trade peace in our time. The reality of the US-China handshake deal at the G20 is not that secure. The deal looks to be a variation on the Juncker-Trump EU handshake deal.

Neil Wilson of Markets.com explains:

8.46am GMT

European stock markets are a sea of green this morning, with gains across the board.

In London, nearly every share is up in

Mayank Mishra, global macro strategist at Standard Chartered, explains:

â€œEven though itâ€™s a 90-days truce and both U.S. and China still need to sort out multiple issues in this period, from marketsâ€™ perspective getting past the event risk with a positive outcome and de-escalation of tensions is clearly positive for risk sentiment.â€�

8.19am GMT

Progress!

8.10am GMT

7.51am GMT

Yuan jumps

7.38am GMT

...but US and China accounts differ

Chinese newspapers have cheered the truce hammered out between Trump and Xi at the G20 leaders meeting.

The timeframe and details on areas of disagreement also did not appear in online reports from Chinaâ€™s state news agency Xinhua, Peopleâ€™s Daily â€” the official Communist Party paper â€” and CGTN â€” the English-language version of state broadcaster CCTV.

The articles did note the U.S. and China agreed to work towards mutual benefits, and generally indicated Beijing would increase purchases of U.S. goods. The state media also said the two parties discussed North Korea denuclearization. The Chinese press also said Trump upheld a â€œOne-China Policyâ€� regarding Taiwan â€” something not mentioned in the White House statement.

7.30am GMT

However, China has NOT backed up the White House claim that the ceasefire will only last for 90 days, unless a permanent trade deal is reached. As CNBC explains: Official online statements about Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yiâ€™s briefing on the meeting did not discuss the technology transfers or the 90-day condition. The timeframe and details on areas of disagreement also did not appear in online reports from Chinaâ€™s state news agency Xinhua, Peopleâ€™s Daily â€” the official Communist Party paper â€” and CGTN â€” the English-language version of state broadcaster CCTV. The articles did note the U.S. and China agreed to work towards mutual benefits, and generally indicated Beijing would increase purchases of U.S. goods. The state media also said the two parties discussed North Korea denuclearization. The Chinese press also said Trump upheld a â€œOne-China Policyâ€� regarding Taiwan â€” something not mentioned in the White House statement. Sue Trinh of Royal Bank of Canada is cautious about this trade truce -- pointing out that the US and China havenâ€™t released a joint statement on what was agreed. But she also believes this is a win for president Trump: Trade wars need to be framed in terms of who hurts the least and see the G20 meeting as a stronger win for the US. China buys 3 months before tariffs on $200bn in goods rise to 25% while the US knows it will have a deal with sizeable China concessions in 90 days, or go ahead with tariffs having cleared the backlog of harvested crops from the agri sector. Tai Hui, chief market strategist for Asia Pacific at J.P. Morgan Asset Management, is also wary, saying: The negotiation is likely to remain challenging given the competition in a number of areas, especially technological development between the two countries. 90 days is not a very long to resolve these differences. The good news is that this truce should be seen as Washington recognising the potential damage on the U.S. economy if tariffs escalate further. We see an ongoing dialogue between the two sides to be an important catalyst for Asian markets to recover lost ground this year, alongside steady global growth and a weaker US dollar.â€� Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. Global stock markets are rallying today on relief that America and China have pulled back from escalating their trade war. In one of the most eagerly awaited dinner dates in a while, Donald Trump and Xi Jinping struck a truce at the end of the G20 meeting in Buenos Aires. After the dinner, Trump declared: â€œThis was an amazing and productive meeting with unlimited possibilities for both the United States and China. It is my great honor to be working with President Xi.â€� However, the agreement is light on detail. We know that America has deferred its plan to raise the tariff on $200bn of Chinese imports from 10% to 25%, for 90 days (it was scheduled for 1 January). This kicks the can down the road a little, teeing up more tense talks before the end of March. In return, China has apparently agreed to purchase a â€œvery substantialâ€� amount of US goods - including farm, energy and industrial products. That would help narrow the massive trade gap between the two countries. Trump has declared that China is also removing tariffs on US car imports -- which would be a win for Americaâ€™s auto sector However, the two sides will now face fraught talks over intellectual property protections, and the threat that the truce could break down at an time. Still, investors are delighted to hear peace ring out. Asian markets have surged overnight, with Chinaâ€™s Shanghai Composite jumping by 2.5%. Thatâ€™s its biggest one-day gain in a month. Australia has gained 1.8%, and Japanâ€™s Nikkei is 1% higher. Stephen Innes of trading firm OANDA says: With the immense weight of the global supply chain dynamic network on their shoulder, a tariff detente has emerged after a highly anticipated dinner. Both Presidentsâ€™ XI and Trump have agreed to put on hold the menacing tariff increases expected to get imposed January 1, marking a significant de-escalation in trade tensions between the worldâ€™s two biggest economies. Thankfully, for risk sentiment, the â€œdinner date of the decadeâ€� ended with a sense of harmony rather than trade war discord. European markets are going to join the party too, and are expected to gain almost 2% at the open.... Also coming up today... We find out how the worldâ€™s factories fared in November, when the latest surveys of purchasing managers are released. Theyâ€™ll probably confirm that the eurozone has slowed sharply, while the US economy is more robust. The agenda 9am GMT: Eurozone manufacturing PMI report for November 9.30am GMT: UK manufacturing PMI report for November 3pm GMT: US manufacturing PMI report for November

KPMG, the auditing firm that gave Carillion a clean bill of health, has reported a leap in profits that will result in the average pay of its 635 partners soaring from Â£519,000 to more than Â£600,000 each.

Only months after KPMG was accused by MPs of being part of a â€œcosy clubâ€� and â€œcomplicitâ€� in the run-up to the collapse of the construction and government outsourcing company, the accountancy group reported an 8% rise in revenue to Â£2.3bn in the 12 months to 30 September. Profits surged 18% to Â£365m.

Related: KPMG cannot fail to profit from lack of competition

Bumper profits helped to boost the pay packets of KPMGâ€™s most senior executives, with the average payout per partner rising to Â£601,000. The chairman, Bill Michael, who was appointed last year, received Â£2.1m.

KPMG was one of the firms singled out in a damning report on the demise of Carillion, which collapsed under a mountain of debt in January.

â€œIn its failure to question Carillionâ€™s financial judgments and information, KPMG was complicit in the companyâ€™s questionable accounting practices, complacently signing off its directorsâ€™ increasingly fantastical figures over its 19-year tenure as Carillionâ€™s auditor,â€� MPs on the work and pensions and the business select committees concluded in May.

KPMG was also fined Â£3m in August by the Financial Reporting Council (FRC) after the firm admitted to misconduct in its audits of the fashion chain Ted Baker in 2013 and 2014. That penalty followed a Â£4.5m fine by the FRC in June, for its audit of Quindell in 2013.

The boost to profits comes at a difficult time for the big four accountancy firms â€“ KPMG, EY, Deloitte and PwC â€“ which have attracted criticism from politicians and regulators over the quality of their audit work and face calls to be broken up.

They were all criticised for failing to spot problems at Carillion sooner and for prioritising profits over proper scrutiny of companies during their audits.

MPs accused the firms of â€œfeastingâ€� on the carcass of Carillion after banking Â£72m for work in the years leading up to the construction firmâ€™s collapse.

Professional firms such as KPMG have also been criticised for conflicts of interest, given the wide array of work done for big clients such as Carillion. It has been claimed that firms are less willing to challenge auditing clients in the hope of winning lucrative contracts for consultancy and advisory work.

However, KPMG stressed in its latest results that it was the first UK firm to â€œvoluntarily stop providing â€˜non-auditâ€™ services to the FTSE 350 companies it auditsâ€�. It has also recommended that the ban is rolled out across all audit firms in the UK.

Michael said: â€œI have been clear that our wider profession faces challenges. In order to safeguard against any perceptions of conflict of interest, we have drawn a clear line between our advisory and audit work for UK-listed businesses.â€�

However, the companyâ€™s deal advisory division grew 14%, while its audit and consulting practices expanded by 8% and 5% respectively.

Prem Sikka, a professor of accounting at the University of Sheffield and lead author of Labourâ€™s review of the audit market, said KPMGâ€™s earnings had benefited from a lack of scrutiny from UK regulators.

â€œIt is only sustainable as long as the regulators donâ€™t do much about their quality and as long as they continue to enjoy the state-guaranteed market,â€� he said. â€œI think the question is not how much money they make and how many clients they have; the question is: what value do they deliver?

â€œIf these people are making this much revenue and theyâ€™re still botching the audits, where are the regulators? Because the fines are incredibly small; incredibly small.â€�

KPMGâ€™s results also detailed its median gender pay gap, which stood at 28%, while the average gap came out at 42%. The median ethnicity pay gap was 14% and stood at 26% on average.

Those figures include employee and partner pay.

9.35pm GMT

Wall Street in late recovery

Hold onto your tin hats!

The New York stock exchange has managed a late rebound. As shares clawed their way back, the Dow has closed just 79 points lower at 24,947 points.

Thatâ€™s a drop of just 0.3% - barely worth mentioning on a normal day.

The tech-focused Nasdaq actually closed 0.4% higher.

Traders are citing optimism that the US central bank, the Federal Reserve, might not raise interest rates as rapidly as expected.

That might help Asia and Europe to regain their poise in Fridayâ€™s trading session.

Until then, goodnight..... GW

8.25pm GMT

Full story: Â£56bn wiped off FTSE 100 as global markets wobble

If youâ€™re just tuning in, hereâ€™s economics editor Larry Elliott on todayâ€™s market gyrations:

The value of the Cityâ€™s leading companies has fallen by more than Â£56bn during waves of selling on stock markets in Asia, Europe and North America prompted by heightened fears of a trade war between the US and China.

The FTSE 100 index suffered its biggest percentage fall since the day after the EU referendum in June 2016 â€“ closing almost 218 points lower at 6,704.

Only three of the 100 companies quoted in the FTSE 100 closed up on a day of heavy and coordinated selling on every major global stock market.

Wall Street was on course for a second day of heavy losses following news of the detention of Meng Wanzhou, chief global finance officer for the Chinese telecoms company Huawei by Canadian authorities and the request by the US for her extradition to face reported cyber espionage and sanction-breaking charges.

Reports of Wanzhouâ€™s arrest â€“ and Chinaâ€™s demand for her release â€“ led to falls of 2% in the Shanghai and Tokyo markets overnight and the sell-off spread to Europe, where all the main bourses saw losses in their main indices of more than 3%.

Frankfurtâ€™s DAX index has now fallen by more than 20% since its peak â€“ the official definition of a bear market â€“ amid concerns that the countryâ€™s manufacturing exporters will be hard hit by an intensification of US-China protectionism....

Hereâ€™s the full piece:

Related: Â£56bn wiped off FTSE 100 in biggest market fall since Brexit vote

8.23pm GMT

Hereâ€™s a reminder of the size and scale of todayâ€™s market selloff - big losses across Europe and the America....

..., after Asia was rocked by the arrest of Huaweiâ€™s Meng Wanzhou.

8.08pm GMT

Dimon: US-China trade 'skirmish' is spooking markets

Jamie Dimon, the CEO of JP Morgan, believes the US-China trade dispute is the primary issue hurting markets.

He told CNBC that investors are worried about how bad the situation will get [a good question, now that Huaweiâ€™s CFO is facing extradition to the US].

CNBC explains:

The U.S. under the Trump administration has engaged in an escalating trade war with China, though the two sides are talking and set a 90 day time frame from Dec. 1 to get an agreement.

Dimon called it a trade â€œskirmish.â€� But it is forcing business leaders to find new supply lines, rethink investments or hold off on investments. â€œThose things are just causing uncertainty, which causes volatility.â€�

8.04pm GMT

8.04pm GMT

With one hour to go until Wall Street closes for the day, the Dow Jones industrial average is solidly in the red.

The Dow is down 350 points - with almost every share still down today. Boeing and JP Morgan lead the fallers

7.42pm GMT

Ian King, Sky Newsâ€™s business editor, reckon president Trump must take responsibility for the falling stock markets.

He writes that Trumpâ€™s trade war with China has alarmed investors, and weakened shares:

Mr Trump, who tweeted regularly when the stock market was breaking new records earlier this year, has had very little to say about these recent falls.

However, if he is being honest with himself, he will know he is to blame.

US equities were euphoric earlier this year on the back of his corporate tax cuts.

However, the sugar rush has now worn off and, in the eyes of company executives, good Trump who cut taxes for companies has been replaced by bad Trump, who erects tariffs and introduces other protectionist measures.

So while thereâ€™s still time for the traditional â€˜Santa rallyâ€™ in the run-up to Christmas, investors shouldnâ€™t bank on it this year.....

7.33pm GMT

7.10pm GMT

Back in New York, shares are bouncing back from their earlier lows.

The Dow is now only down 330 points, or 1.3% -- a chunky fall, but less severe than the 700-point slump earlier.

Itâ€™s turning into another volatile day....

Updated at 7.14pm GMT

7.04pm GMT

Fears of a global downturn have hit markets today, says Patrick Schaffer, global investment specialist at J.P. Morgan Private Bank.

â€œThe market seems right now to be focused on increased risks for a 2020 recession.

â€œItâ€™s a very hard market to buy when you see really strong signals that we are indeed late (in the economic) cycle.â€�

7.04pm GMT

The market mayhem may bring some relief to hard-pressed US consumers. The odds of American interest rates being hiked in 2019 have fallen sharply.

6.42pm GMT

The big picture is that most global stock markets have lost ground this year.

The FTSE 100 was already down more than 10% since the start of January, before todayâ€™s rout. The German DAX was down 16%, while Chinaâ€™s market has plunged by a fifth.

America has done better, mainly due to the impact of Donald Trumpâ€™s tax cuts (which have boosted corporate profits).

6.31pm GMT

6.30pm GMT

Sky News have a good take on the selloff:

A global share sell-off has seen the FTSE 100 slump on the same scale as the day after the Brexit referendum in 2016.

The decline of 3.15%, or 218 points - wiping Â£56bn off the value of the FTSEâ€™s constituent companies - came after the arrest of a top Chinese executive on behalf of the US triggered renewed fears of a trade war.

That helped unleash simmering worries about a broad cocktail of worldwide tensions, including a potential recession in the US, turning trading screens red from New York and London to Paris and Frankfurt.

A slide in the oil price - with Brent crude falling by more than 3% to less than $60 a barrel - also weighed on sentiment.

6.20pm GMT

Back in New York, Wall Street continues to suffer its own day of losses.

The Dow Jones industrial average is currently down 500-ish points, or 2%, at 24,517. That means the benchmark index has lost all its gains for 2018.

The broader S&P 500 index has shed 1.5%, which means it is also in the red for 2018.

6.14pm GMT

Analyst: Brexit means FTSE 100 is desperately unloved

Todayâ€™s sell-off also means the FTSE 100 is actually below its level on 30th December 1999, the final day of the last millennium.

However, thereâ€™s a bit more to it than that.

For starters, the FTSE 100 is still almost double its nadir in March 2009, when the financial crisis had driven Britain into recession.

Secondly, the raw points value of the Footsie doesnâ€™t include the dividends paid out to shareholders from company profits.

According to Laith Khalaf of financial services firm Hargreaves Lansdown, youâ€™d actually have doubled your money if youâ€™d invested at the end of the dot-com boom.

He also puts some of the blame for the losses on the Brexit crisis....

Today, sentiment is vastly different from the end of the 1990s. Animal spirits were out of control in 1999, which led to the substantial overvaluation of the UK stock market. Now the Footsie is desperately unloved because Brexit means many investors want to put a good-sized bargepole between themselves and the UK stock market.

Despite the headline value of the FTSE 100 today being close to its 1999 peak, investors in the UK stock market are putting money to work at a much cheaper level, once you take company profits into account. In 1999 the UK stock market was valued at 27 times earnings, today it stands at around 15 times earnings. While in the short term itâ€™s entirely plausible the UK market could fall further, a lower valuation suggests better long term returns are on offer.

6.00pm GMT

Mohamed El-Erian of Allianz reckons that shares took a dive today as investors raced to sell riskier assets, fearing more turmoil ahead.

5.55pm GMT

Fiona Cincotta, senior market analyst at City Index, says the shock arrest of Huaweiâ€™s CFO was a big factor behind todayâ€™s market meltdown.

For China the Huawei arrest will add insult to injury as the arrested executive, Meng Wangzhou, is not only the companyâ€™s CFO but also the Huawei founderâ€™s daughter and the prospective company successor and concerns are growing that the country could retaliate with arrests of US executives.

Although Meng Wangzhou was detained in Canada on suspicions of breaching sanctions against Iran the arrest highlights a different set of tensions between the US and China â€“ the issue of cybersecurity. The US has long suspected Huawei of foul play in cybersecurity and has restricted the sale of its 5G equipment in the US for fears that it might be used for dubious purposes.

5.46pm GMT

Todayâ€™s sell-off has driven the FTSE 100 index down to its lowest close in over two years.

5.41pm GMT

Why are markets sliding today

If youâ€™re just tuning in, there are three reasons why markets are falling sharply today.

1) News broke last night that the chief financial officer of one of Chinaâ€™s biggest companies, Meng Wanzhou of Huawei, has been arrested in Canada.

Meng faces extradition to the US, reportedly on charges of cyber-espionage and breaking sanctions preventing trade with Iran.

Her shock detention has panicked investors, who fear that it will destabilise negotiations between the US and China over trade policies.

Related: China demands release of Huawei executive arrested in Canada

2) Global slowdown fears are growing. Economic data this week has shown that Europeâ€™s companies have slowed, while the UKâ€™s services sector also ran out of steam last month.

3) Ructions in the bond markets. Nervous investors are now demanding a greater return for buying short-term US government debt, rather than longer dated. This â€˜yield curve inversionâ€™ could be a sign that Americaâ€™s economy is heading for recession.

5.38pm GMT

In points terms, the FTSE 100 has suffered its biggest drop in over three years.

5.19pm GMT

A reminder that all European markets suffered a bad day:

5.18pm GMT

Nearly every company on the FTSE 100 fell today, apart from precious metals producers (who benefitted from a dash into gold and silver).

Energy firms slumped by 4.5%, mining companies fell 4%, banks lost 3.9%, and industrial groups lost 2.7%.

4.52pm GMT

FTSE 100 suffers worst day since EU referendum

After a day of wild selling, and deepening losses, Londonâ€™s stock market has just posted its biggest one-day loss since the UK voted to leave the European Union.

The FTSE 100 has just closed down 217 points, a fall of 3.15%, at 6704.

That matches the 3.15% decline suffered in the aftermath of the EU referendum, on 24 June 2016.

By my maths, it wipes Â£56bn off the value of the companies on the Footsie.

More to follow!

Updated at 5.42pm GMT

4.35pm GMT

Europe suffers worst day since Brexit vote

European stock markets have suffered their worst day since Britain voted to leave the EU.

The Stoxx 600 index, which includes Europeâ€™s biggest stocks, has just closed for the night, down 3.3%.

Germanyâ€™s DAX has provisionally closed down 3.9%, which I think puts it in an official bear market (down more than a fifth on its record high).

Amid panicky selling, the French CAC has lost 3.7% and Spainâ€™s IBEX shed 3.2%.

4.29pm GMT

The selloff on Wall Street is deepening, fast.

The Dow has now tumbled by 760 points, as the rout accelerates.

Each of the 30 members of the Dow is in the red.

Aircraft-maker Boeing has lost 6.6%, chemicals firm DowDuPont has lost 4.4%, investment bank JP Morgan has dropped by 3.8% and construction equipment maker Caterpillar has lost 3.3%.

4.24pm GMT

Britainâ€™s stock market has just endured one of its worst days in several years....

4.07pm GMT

Hereâ€™s David Madden, market analyst at CMC Markets UK, on todayâ€™s market mayhem:

Equity markets suffered severe losses as investors are worried the relationship between the US and China has been strained by the arrest of Meng Wanzhou, the CFO of Huawei.

The Chinese businesswomen faces possible extradition to the US as the company is alleged to have breached sanctions in relation to Iran. The US-China relationship was moving in the right direction after the G20 summit, and now dealers feel all the good work could be undone.

It is a broad based sell-off that we are seeing in London, as mining, energy, financial and consumer stocks are all lower.

4.05pm GMT

Hereâ€™s the scene on the New York stock exchange today, as traders reel from another heavy sell-off:

3.54pm GMT

Thereâ€™s no respite on Wall Street. Instead, the Dow is now down by 525 points, or 2.1%.

3.29pm GMT

German investors flee, pursued by a bear market

Over in Frankfurt, the DAX index has slumped by over 3%.

That takes the index of leading German companies into a full-blown bear market, more than 20% below its recent peak.

Carmaker Daimler is the biggest faller, down 5.3%. Industrial giant Thyssenkrupp have lost 4.5% and pharmaceuticals company Bayer has lost 3.6%. They would all be big casualties from a deep global trade war.

3.08pm GMT

Back in London, shares are hitting new two-year lows.

The FTSE 100 index has now slumped by 2.8%, or 196 points, to 6724.

Mining giant Antofagasta has now slumped by 7%, reflecting concerns that the US-China trade truce may not hold.

Financial stocks such as Prudential(-6.7%), Schroders (-5.7%), Legal & General (-4.8%) and Royal Bank of Scotland (-4%) are also among the top fallers.

Updated at 3.16pm GMT

3.03pm GMT

US banks fall as yield curve inversion spooks markets

Americaâ€™s banks are also being pummelled in early trading, on fears of an economic slowdown.

Bank of America has shed 4%, while JP Morgan has lost over 3%.

Traders are alarmed by recent moves in the US bond market. The yield, or interest rate, on US two-year bonds has risen above the yields on longer-dated five-year bonds.

Technically, that means the yield curve has â€˜invertedâ€™, and that investors are demanding a higher interest rate to hold short-dated bonds.

Why does THAT matter? Because it suggests thereâ€™s a greater risk that the US economy is heading towards a recession (making shorter-dated bonds riskier).

Now, the curve is only just inverted. According to my Reuters machine, the two-year Treasury bills are yielding 2.713%, while 5-year Treasuries are yielding 2.708%.

But thatâ€™s enough to worry Wall Street, who remember that an inverted yield curve has preceded a downturn in the past...

2.42pm GMT

Shares in US semiconductor-makers are leading the selloff on Wall Street.

Broadcom, Micron, Intel and AMD are all in the red; theyâ€™d suffer badly if the US-China trade dispute intensifies, as so many tech products are assembled in Chinese factories.

Appleâ€™s shares have fallen 2%.... and the smaller tech firms which supply chips and other components for iPads, iPhones and Macs are also suffering.

2.33pm GMT

Wall Street tumbles at the open

DING DING! The Wall Street opening bell is being rung, kicking off what could be a brutal trading session.

The Dow Jones industrial average has dropped by 1.85%, or 466 points, to 24,560.

The S&P 500 (a broader measure of US stocks) is also down 1.7%, meaning it is now in the red for 2018.

The tech-focused Nasdaq has lost almost 2%, as traders fear that the arrest of Huaweiâ€™s CFO will hurt the technology sector, and trigger a deeper trade war between the US and China.

More to follow!

2.29pm GMT

Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at Spartan Capital Securities, says traders need their best tin hats today:

â€œThe indices are headed for another tumble as the previous steep sell-off extends itself on a host of negative news.

The arrest of Huawei CFO is putting in doubt the trade truce between the U.S. and China.â€�

2.24pm GMT

Unless Wall Street traders recover their nerve very quickly, weâ€™re heading into a hefty selloff at the open.

The Dow Jones industrial average is expected to drop by more than more than 1.5%, which would be 400 point-plus plunge.

2.04pm GMT

Time for a a quick catch-up on the markets, as we brace for a bruising Wall Street open in under 30 minuteâ€™s time.

Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 is still wallowing at a two-year low, down 172 points or 2.5% at 6748.

The German DAX and the French CAC are both also down 2.5%, dragging the Europe-wide Stoxx 600 down to its own two-year low.

That follows the selloff in Asia, which saw Chinaâ€™s Shanghai Composite index slide by 2%.

Mihir Kapadia, CEO of Sun Global Investments, blames the arrest of Huwaeiâ€™s Chief Financial Officer, Meng Wanzhou.

This is likely to escalate the tense relationship between China and the US further. Both tech and automotive stocks have been the biggest fallers - the events emphasise the vulnerability of markets to any issues, particularly political ones, involving the worldâ€™s two largest economies.

This has sent shockwaves not only across European stock markets but around the world with Asia the worst affected as investorsâ€™ early optimism about the weekend developments in trade talks dissipates. This is likely to set up a turbulent end to the year for markets and will leave investors anxiously awaiting the next development.â€�

1.46pm GMT

US trade deficit hits 10-year high

Newsflash: Americaâ€™s trade gap with China has hit a record high; news that may send Donald Trumpâ€™s blood pressure rising too.

According to the Commerce Department, the deficit swelled by 1.7% last month to $55.5bn, the highest since October 2008. The gap was driven by a surge in imports and a drop in soybean exports (which have been hit by the trade war.)

This means that despite (or indeed thanks to) Trumpâ€™s efforts, Americaâ€™s trade gap has expanded for the last five months.

Crucially, the goods trade deficit with China surged 7.1% to a record $43.1bn.

So much for Trumpâ€™s claim that â€œTrade wars are good, and easy to winâ€�......

The gap was driven by a surge in imports and a drop in soybean exports (which have been hit by the trade war.) This means that despite (or indeed thanks to) Trumpâ€™s efforts, Americaâ€™s trade gap has expanded for the last five months. Crucially, the goods trade deficit with China surged 7.1% to a record $43.1bn. So much for Trumpâ€™s claim that â€œTrade wars are good, and easy to winâ€�...... The latest US jobs data isnâ€™t too encouraging. American companies hired 179,000 new workers last month, according to payroll firm ADP. Thatâ€™s 16,000 fewer than expected, and may show that the US labor market has peaked. How big is Meng Wanzhouâ€™s arrest? Massive, argues Politicoâ€™s Marty Kady: Brad Bechtel of US investment bank Jefferies thinks Meng Wanzhouâ€™s arrest could trigger a new front in the US-China trade war. He writes: Everyone is focused on the Hauwei CFOâ€™s arrest in Canada on allegations that Hauwei violated Iran sanctions. The arrest was ordered by the US and extradition is expected. Concern of course that the arrest will damage the fragile trade truce between the two nations. If anything it tells you the administrationâ€™s willingness to continue to toe the hard line on this issue and to not back down. It leads me to believe we will have a rocky road on this for the next few months and that the game has not yet begun. This was my initial reaction after the weekendâ€™s G20 and the Trump / Xi dinner and last nightâ€™s price action and reaction to the arrest confirms it. The fireworks will continue straight through our winter time. Shortly after news of Mang Wanzhouâ€™s shock arrest broke, China announced that it will immediately start implementing its side of the trade truce with America. Commerce ministry spokesman Gao Feng told reporters that: â€œChina will immediately implement the consensus both sides already reached on agricultural products, energy, autos and other specific items.â€� Gao added that two sides would also discuss intellectual property protection, technology cooperation, market access and fair trade. These measures were agreed between president Trump and President Xi on Saturday night, but thereâ€™s been no official joint announcement of what they actually are. More here: China expert George Magnus has tweeted about why the arrest of Huaweiâ€™s chief financial officer last weekend matters: The European technology sector has slumped by 3.3% today, helping to drag markets down to two-year lows. The arrest of Huaweiâ€™s Meng Wanzhou is fuelling fears that the US-China trade war will flare up again. Any additional tariffs on Chinese exports would hurt tech companies -- last week, Donald Trump mused about slapping new tariffs on iPhones, for example. Energy shares are down 3.2%, reflecting the drop in the oil price as Opec ministers wrestle in Vienna. Mining stocks have dropped by 3% - demand for iron ore, copper, nickel and other commodities will be hit if the global economy stumbles over a trade war. Banks are down 2.7% on average -- theyâ€™d incur more bad debts in a global recession. Industrial companies have lost 2.7%, reflecting worries that order books could shrivel in a trade war. America is waking up to the news that markets are sliding.... The sell-off is turning into a full-blown slump! European stocks have plunged to their lowest level since December 2016, as investors become increasingly panicky. Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 continues to bear a lot of damage - down around 2.5% this morning at its lowest level since December 2016. The German DAX has shed 2.4%, with France, Italy and Spain also under the cosh. Hereâ€™s the damage: There are several reasons for the slump: 1) The shock arrest of Huaweiâ€™s chief financial officer could trigger a new clash in the US-China trade war, undermining hopes of a peace deal. Fiona Cincotta of City Index explains: Asian markets were knocked sideways by the arrest of a senior Huawei official in Canada as the move sparked fears that tensions between the US and China would yet again intensify. FTSE, European gauges and Dow futures were also not spared with the heavily export-oriented DAX losing 1.5%. Tech stocks in Asia were the hardest hit, in particular Samsung, Tokyo Electron, TDK and Tencent, pulling down Asian indexes. The US already has a low-key conflict simmering with the Chinese tech giant and has, alongside New Zealand, already blocked Huawei from selling their 5G technology in the country for fear that it could be used for malicious purposes. The latest arrest will be seen as a heavy slap in the face in China as the arrested executive, Meng Wanzhou, is the companyâ€™s CFO and the daughter of Huaweiâ€™s founder. She was detained in Canada and could end up being extradited to the US as the company is suspected of breaching sanctions against Iran. 2) The Brexit crisis is alarming the City, as Theresa May struggles to persuade MPs to back her withdrawal agreement. Kallum Pickering of Berenberg Bank says: For different reasons, a majority of MPs in parliament seem set to vote down Mrs Mayâ€™s deal on the first attempt. With the lower risk of a hard Brexit, Conservative Remainers might feel less compelled now to back the deal in a second vote. Ironically, Mrs Mayâ€™s chances could now lie in the hands of the Brexiteers. If they realise the game for a hard Brexit is up, they might prefer the deal to the other options of a softer Brexit or no Brexit at all. But this is a long shot. We cut the chances for Mrs Mayâ€™s deal to 25% from 45%. We now see: a 20% chance that the UK will sign up to the EU customs union and single market for goods (up from 10%); a 20% chance that the UK will remain in the European Economic Area via entry into the European Free Trade Association (the Norway option, up from 12.5%); and a 25% chance that Brexit is reversed (up from 12.5%) 3) The oil price is suddenly slumping, as Opec ministers meet in Vienna today. City traders are losing confidence that Opec will agree a sharp output cut to prop up crude prices. This has sent Brent crude slumping by 5% to below $59 per barrel. Wall Street is heading for heavy losses in four hours time. The Dow Jones industrial average is currently expected to plunge by around 500 points, adding to its 800-point lurch on Tuesday (Wall Street was closed yesterday). Anxiety over Brexit is pushing shares down, compounding trade war fears, says Vincent-FreÄ›deÄ›ric Mivelaz of Swissquote Bank. Asian shares continue down, after Canadian authorities confirmed the arrest of Huawei Technologiesâ€™ CFO Wanzhou Meng on charges of violating the USAâ€™s sanctions on exports to Iran. Japanâ€™s Nikkei 225 dropped by 1.91% while Hong Kongâ€™s Hang Seng and Chinaâ€™s CSI 300 declined 2.47% and 2.16%, their most in two weeks. European shares are also dropping, as the UK Parliament mutinies over the Prime Minister Mayâ€™s Brexit plan. The Euro Stoxx 600 has hit a 2-year low while Germanyâ€™s DAX and Franceâ€™s CAC 40 slid 1.90% and 1.85%. Trade discussions between the USA and China officially started this week and are expected to continue for the coming 3 months. Investors are worried, especially about semiconductor manufacturers being hard hit. The FTSE 250 index, which contains smaller, UK-focused companies, is also taking a bath. Itâ€™s currently on track for its biggest one-day fall since the rout after the EU referendum - currently down 460 points, or 2.5%, at 17809. This takes the FTSE 200 down to its lowest level since December 2016. Itâ€™s turning into a rout in London. The FTSE 100 has now slumped by 176 points, or 2.5% -- on track for its worst daily performance since February! Although Meng Wanzhouâ€™s arrest is a shock, Huawei has been facing growing criticism for several years. The Financial Times points out that the US intelligence services have been concerned about the security implications of using Huaweiâ€™s hardware: Huawei has been in the sights of US security officials, and the latest move comes as the Trump administration takes an aggressive stance towards China. In a speech in October, Mike Pence, the US vice-president, put China on notice that Mr Trump was prepared to take a harder stance against Beijing than his predecessors. The Shenzhen-based group has long been a lightning rod for concern about corporate espionage and cyber security. Western intelligence officials worry that reliance on Huawei by other countries could allow China to penetrate foreign telecom networks. Huawei has repeatedly denied having any connection to the Chinese security services or military, insisting it is a privately owned company. But it has struggled to erase doubts because [founder] Mr Ren is a former Peopleâ€™s Liberation Army officer. Britainâ€™s security service also have concerns. On Monday the head of MI6 said ministers had to decide whether to use Huawei in Britainâ€™s new 5G networks. BT has already decided to removing Huawei equipment from key areas of its 4G network, as part of an infrastructure overhaul. Emerging economy stock markets are having a particularly bad week: Worries over global economic growth, rising interest rates and the US/China trade war are all driving markets down, says Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell. He agrees that the arrest of Huaweiâ€™s CFO has alarmed investors, who fear it will â€œstir up tensions between China and the US.â€� Nearly every share on the FTSE 100 is down -- apart from Imperial Brands, British American Tobacco, Diageo, Severn Trent and National Grid. â€œAll these are considered to be defensive stocks, offering goods and services people would buy regardless of economic conditions. Diageo is perhaps an exception as an alcohol seller yet investors often turn to large, robust business in times of strife. That may also explain why Unilever and Compass declined much less than the broader market. â€œThe fallers were led by mining stocks which are always sensitive to any fears over the global economy and China. This chart shows how the FTSE 100 is back below its level at the end of the last millennium, just before the dot-com boom ended. Thatâ€™s not the full story, of course, as this doesnâ€™t show the dividends paid out in the last 18 years. But even then, the picture isnâ€™t sparkling - especially once you look in dollar terms: The selloff in London is gathering pace! The FTSE 100 has now shed 1.5%, or 110 points, leaving it firmly slumped at a two-year low. Most stocks are down, with financial stocks, miners and energy companyâ€™s losing the most. Industrial group Melrose is the biggest faller, with major mining companies such as Glencore and Antofagasta close behind. Stocks are down across Europe too. The Stoxx 600 index has hit a six-week low, dragged down by technology stocks and car makers (who would both suffer from a US-China war). The City is reeling from the fallout following the arrest of Huaweiâ€™s Meng Wanzhou, says Connor Campbell of SpreadEx: Jeez it has been an intense week for US-China relations. The post-G20 trade truce is starting to feel like a distant memory, with Tariff Man Donald Trump, and now the arrest of Huaweiâ€™s Meng Wanzhou, serving to undermine whatever (naÃ¯ve) hopes of progress had built up on Monday. Wanzhou, global chief financial officer of telecoms equipment at the Shenzen-based smartphone firm and daughter of its founder, was detained in Canada last Saturday and is now facing extradition to the USA, relating to an investigation into whether or not she violated sanctions against Iran. Ouch! Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 has fallen by over 80 points at the start of trading, a drop of 1.2%. That takes the blue-chip index of top shares in the City down to 6840 points, its lowest level in two years. The arrest of Huaweiâ€™s Meng Wanzhou has spooked traders, who are already unsettled by Brexit uncertainty, and the prospect that the global economy is slowing. Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets writes: The latest bout of anxiety stems from the arrest and planned extradition from Canada to the US of the CFO (and founderâ€™s Daughter) of Chinese telecom giant Huawei, on allegations of breaching Iran sanctions and suspicions of cyber-espionage. Having swung between optimism and scepticism about a US-China trade war truce through February, and we note Chinese diplomats making positive noise overnight (â€œfriendly and candid atmosphereâ€� between Xi and Trump), traders are understandably cautious. Todayâ€™s losses also take the FTSE 100 below its level at the end of the last millennium! (when the FTSE 100 closed at 6,930 points). Huawei is insisting on Meng Wanzhouâ€™s release, insisting they arenâ€™t away of any misconduct: Technology stocks have been hit particularly hard in Asia today. In Hong Kong, Tencent was off more than 4%, while AAC and Sunny Optical each fell around 6%. South Koreaâ€™s Samsung Electronics shed 2%. Meng Wanzhouâ€™s arrest will probably exacerbate tensions between the US and China, my colleague Lily Kuo reports: US authorities have been investigating Huawei since at least 2016 for allegedly shipping US-origin products to Iran and other countries in violation of US export and sanctions laws, sources told Reuters in April. Huawei, one of the worldâ€™s largest makers of telecommunications network equipment, said in a statement that Meng had been â€œtemporarily detainedâ€� and faced unspecified allegationsâ€� in the Eastern district of New York. The company said it had complied with â€œall applicable laws and regulations where it operates,â€� including sanction laws. â€œThere has been very little information provided to Huawei on the specific allegations. Huawei is not aware of any misconduct by Ms. Meng,â€� Guo Ping, rotating CEO of the company said in a statement posted on his Wechat account on Thursday. â€œThe company believes the Canadian and US legal systems will ultimately reach a just conclusion,â€� he said. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. A chilly wave of fear is rippling through the markets today, after a leading Chinese executive was arrested in Canada. Meng Wanzhou, the global chief financial officer of telecoms equipment Huawei, is facing extradition to the US -- reportedly to face charges of violating sanctions against Iran. The arrest of Meng -- whoâ€™s also the daughter of Huaweiâ€™s founder -- has rocked Asia-Pacific markets, and is likely to spark fresh jitters in Europe and the US. It threatens to reignite the trade war clashes between Washington and Beijing, just days after the two countryâ€™s leaders agreed a truce. The Chinese stock market has slumped by 2%, and there are heavy losses in Tokyo and Hong Kong too: Jasper Lawler of London Capital Group says sentiment has been â€˜smashedâ€™ this morning. Asian markets and US futures plummeted overnight as news broke that Huaweiâ€™s CFO had been arrested in Canada to be extradited back to the US. The CFO, Wanzhou Meng, was arrested for allegedly breaching Iran sanctions. China criticized the US and Canada for the arrest, demanding her immediate release. Traders have quickly moved out of riskier assets reflecting nerves that the arrest is likely to escalate tensions between the US and China once again. The timing is fascinating, incidentally. Meng was apparently arrested 1 December, the very day that Donald Trump and Xi Jinping were enjoying dinner together at the G20 meeting in Buenos Aires. Investors will fear that the shock detention of such a significant business figure could easily anger the Chinese government, and potentially scupper plans to buy more US goods. Also coming up today Oil ministers are gathering in Vienna for an Opec meeting, where the cartel is widely expected to agree a production cut. A chunky reduction to output might push oil prices higher....on the other hand, investors may already have priced it in! Brent crude is trading around $61 per barrel this morning, around 20% lower than two months ago. Donald Trump has already chipped in: Plus, we get new manufacturing and employment data from the US. The agenda 9am GMT: Opec meeting scheduled to begin 1.30pm GMT: US weekly jobless figures 3pm GMT: US factory orders
